https://prez.dev/description.@value: A categorization of disciplines or topics that the broad field of Earth science can be subdivided into, i.e. a listing of the Fields of Research, or subjects, to which a geoscience dataset, publication, observation/activity, or entity pertains. The vocabulary also contains relevant disciplines that intersect with the various Earth science fields, such as biological sciences and built environment and design, as well as entries related to collection and heritage management. Notations included are those from the 2020 ANZSRC listing (see History Note) or in common use in the geoscience community.

The science and art of making maps and charts, and the specific use of digital technologies (mapping tools and software) to create seamless geographical displays of data as an image on a computer screen.

Geographic Information Science (GIScience) is the basic research field that seeks to redefine geographic concepts and their use in the context of geographic information systems. GIScience also examines the impacts of GIS on individuals and society, and the influences of society on GIS. GIScience re-examines some of the most fundamental themes in traditional spatially oriented fields such as geography, cartography, and geodesy, while incorporating more recent developments in cognitive and information science

http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#defi.@value: A professional engineering discipline that focuses on spatial information (i.e. information that has a location) to design, develop, and operate systems for collecting and analysing spatial information about the land, the oceans, natural resources, and man-made features.

http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#hist.@value: From the Fields of Research vocabulary from the Australian and New Zealand Standard Research Classification (ANZSRC, 2020). Definition adapted from Wikipedia.

https://prez.dev/description.@value: A professional engineering discipline that focuses on spatial information (i.e. information that has a location) to design, develop, and operate systems for collecting and analysing spatial information about the land, the oceans, natural resources, and man-made features.
Geomatic engineering data and information not otherwise described by other sub-categories of geomatics engineering.

The discipline concerned with the collection, distribution, storage, analysis, processing, presentation of geographic data or geographic information, as well as the products, services and tools involved in the collection, integration and management of geographic (geospatial) data.

https://prez.dev/label.@value: geospatial information systems and geospatial data modelling

https://prez.dev/description.@value: The application of geographic information systems (GIS), i.e. an integrated computer hardware and software, to store, manage, analyse, edit, output, visualize and model geographic data.

The science and technology of collecting/measuring, processing, analysing and interpreting information from noncontact imaging and other sensor systems that record the interaction between electromagnetic energy and matter, i.e. the acquisition of information about an object or phenomenon by using a recording device that is not in physical contact with the subject being studied. Aerial photographs and imagery acquired from a satellite or drone are examples of remotely sensed information.

The use of satellites to determine the location (geographic position) of a receiver on Earth. The technique involves measuring the range between the receiver and the satellite, and the range measurement used to calculate the receiver's position using observation equations and least squares. The technique is used in global and regional satellite navigation systems.

The applied science of determining the two-dimensional or three-dimensional positions of points necessary to determine the area of any part of the Earth's (or other planetary body) surface, the lengths and directions of the boundary lines, and the contour of the surface, and of accurately delineating the whole on paper/digitally.
